DataElement.preferredName: Malignant Neoplasm Fludeoxyglucose F 18 Positron Emission Tomography Uptake Assessment Finding Lesion Soft Tissue Uptake
DataElement.preferredDefinition: Status of FDG-PET uptake for soft tissue lesion

DataElementConcept.preferredName: Malignant Neoplasm Fludeoxyglucose F 18 Positron Emission Tomography Uptake Assessment Finding
DataElementConcept.preferredDefinition: information related to the uptake or abosorbtion of Fludeoxyglucose F 18 (FDG), the radioactive form of glucose used in positron emission tomography (PET) assessment, of a malignant neoplasm, a tumor composed of atypical neoplastic, often pleomorphic cells that invade other tissues.

ObjectClass.preferredDefinition: A tumor composed of atypical neoplastic, often pleomorphic cells that invade other tissues.  Malignant neoplasms usually metastasize to distant anatomic sites and may recur after excision.  The most common malignant neoplasms are carcinomas (adenocarcinomas or squamous cell carcinomas), Hodgkin's and non-Hodgkin's lymphomas, leukemias, melanomas, and sarcomas. -- 2004

Concepts.definition: A neoplasm composed of atypical neoplastic, often pleomorphic cells that invade other tissues. Malignant neoplasms often metastasize to distant anatomic sites and may recur after excision. The most common malignant neoplasms are carcinomas, Hodgkin and non-Hodgkin lymphomas, leukemias, melanomas, and sarcomas.

Property.preferredName: Fludeoxyglucose F 18 Positron Emission Tomography Uptake Assessment Finding
Property.preferredDefinition: The radioactive form of glucose used in positron emission tomography (PET), a diagnostic imaging procedure.:A technique for measuring the gamma radiation produced by collisions of electrons and positrons (anti-electrons) within living tissue. In positron emission tomography (PET), a subject is given a dose of a positron-emitting radionuclide attached to a metabolically active substance (for example, 2-fluoro-2-deoxy-D-glucose (FDG), which is similar to a naturally occurring sugar, glucose, with the addition of a radioactive fluorine atom). When living tissue containing the positron emitter is bombarded by electrons, gamma radiation produced by collisions of electrons and positrons is detected by a scanner, revealing in fine detail the tissue location of the metabolically-active substance administered.:The absorption by a tissue of some substance, food material, mineral, etc., and its permanent or temporary retention.:Having determined the value, significance, or extent of.:Clinical, laboratory or molecular evidence, or absence of evidence of disease.

Concepts.definition: A positron-emitting radiopharmaceutical containing radioactive 2-deoxy-2-[18F] fluoro-D-glucose. With similar cell uptake as glucose (high in tumor cells), fludeoxyglucose F 18 is not dephosphorylated and further metabolized. (NCI04)

A technique for measuring the gamma radiation produced by collisions of electrons and positrons (anti-electrons) within living tissue. In positron emission tomography (PET), a subject is given a dose of a positron-emitting radionuclide attached to a metabolically active substance (for example, 2-fluoro-2-deoxy-D-glucose (FDG), which is similar to a naturally occurring sugar, glucose, with the addition of a radioactive fluorine atom). When living tissue containing the positron emitter is bombarded by electrons, gamma radiation produced by collisions of electrons and positrons is detected by a scanner, revealing in fine detail the tissue location of the metabolically-active substance administered.
The absorption by a tissue of some substance, food material, mineral, etc., and its permanent or temporary retention.
The final result of a determination of the value, significance, or extent of.
Clinical, laboratory or molecular evidence, or absence of evidence of disease.

ConceptualDomain.preferredDefinition: the response criteria (includes RECIST and others) and associated documentation of disease.

DataElementConcept.origin: COG CRF:Children's Oncology Group Case Report Form
DataElementConcept.changeDescription: Changed from CTEP to COG for by script Thu Jan 2 10:00:57 EST 2014

ValueDomain.preferredName: Lesion Soft Tissue Uptake Uptake Status
ValueDomain.preferredDefinition: A localized pathological or traumatic structural change, damage, deformity, or discontinuity of tissue, organ, or body part._Lacking in hardness relatively or comparatively._An anatomical structure consisting of similarly specialized cells and intercellular matrix, aggregated according to genetically determined spatial relationships, performing a specific function._The absorption by a tissue of some substance, food material, mineral, etc., and its permanent or temporary retention._The absorption by a tissue of some substance, food material, mineral, etc., and its permanent or temporary retention._A condition or state at a particular time.

ValueMeaning.preferredDefinition: The absorption by a tissue of some substance, food material, mineral, etc., and its permanent or temporary retention.: A means of finding a solution to a problem, or a means of finding agreement or harmony.: An imaging technique that utilizes positron emission tomography to produce a three-dimensional image of functional processes in the body. The system detects pairs of gamma rays emitted indirectly by a positron-emitting radionuclide (tracer), which is introduced into the body on the biologically active molecule (fludeoxyglucose) FDG. FDG is an analogue of glucose which when imaged will give tissue metabolic activity, in terms of regional glucose uptake.

Concepts.definition: The absorption by a tissue of some substance, food material, mineral, etc., and its permanent or temporary retention.
A means of finding a solution to a problem, or a means of finding agreement or harmony.

An imaging technique that utilizes positron emission tomography to produce a three-dimensional image of functional processes in the body. The system detects pairs of gamma rays emitted indirectly by a positron-emitting radionuclide (tracer), which is introduced into the body on the biologically active molecule (fludeoxyglucose) FDG. FDG is an analogue of glucose which when imaged will give tissue metabolic activity, in terms of regional glucose uptake.

PermissibleValues.value: New lesion that is FDG-PET avid

ValueMeaning.preferredDefinition: A localized pathological or traumatic structural change, damage, deformity, or discontinuity of tissue, organ, or body part.: A technique for measuring the gamma radiation produced by collisions of electrons and positrons (anti-electrons) within living tissue. In positron emission tomography (PET), a subject is given a dose of a positron-emitting radionuclide attached to a metabolically active substance (for example, 2-fluoro-2-deoxy-D-glucose (FDG), which is similar to a naturally occurring sugar, glucose, with the addition of a radioactive fluorine atom). When living tissue containing the positron emitter is bombarded by electrons, gamma radiation produced by collisions of electrons and positrons is detected by a scanner, revealing in fine detail the tissue location of the metabolically-active substance administered.: Having no previous example or precedent or parallel; of a kind not seen before.

Concepts.definition: A localized pathological or traumatic structural change, damage, deformity, or discontinuity of tissue, organ, or body part.

A technique for measuring the gamma radiation produced by collisions of electrons and positrons (anti-electrons) within living tissue. In positron emission tomography (PET), a subject is given a dose of a positron-emitting radionuclide attached to a metabolically active substance (for example, 2-fluoro-2-deoxy-D-glucose (FDG), which is similar to a naturally occurring sugar, glucose, with the addition of a radioactive fluorine atom). When living tissue containing the positron emitter is bombarded by electrons, gamma radiation produced by collisions of electrons and positrons is detected by a scanner, revealing in fine detail the tissue location of the metabolically-active substance administered.
Having no previous example or precedent or parallel; of a kind not seen before.
